variant.question: What (amongst other) is the purpose for consulting an SWC chart prior to flight?

options.text: To avoid areas with turbulence.
To obtain weather information for a VFR flight only.
To obtain all necessary weather forecasts for the entire route of flight.
To obtain exact weather information for the destination airport.

variant.question:
When 1 hour away from the destination, the pilot receives notification that tornado activity is observed 10 NM from the airport, moving towards the airport and away from the direction in which the aircraft is flying.
Based on this information, the best course of action for the pilot is to...

options.text: reduce the aircraft speed, as a typical tornado would pass over the airport in approximately 20 to 40 minutes.
continue according to the flight plan, as a typical tornado would pass over the airport in approximately 6 minutes.
continue according to the flight plan, as a typical tornado would pass over the airport in approximately 3 minutes.
adjust the aircraft speed, as a typical tornado would be over the airport in approximately 90 minutes.

variant.question: How are pilot reports of significant weather in flight subsequently used by the receiving meteorological office and their systems?

options.text: The reports can be processed into weather models to improve subsequent forecasts.
The relevant Meteorological Watch Office will process the report and issue a SPECI.
The reports can be directly used in weather prediction systems and processed into PIREPs.
The meteorological office will re-broadcast these reports because they are incompatible with digital weather processing systems.

variant.question:
The crew of an aircraft flying from London Heathrow (EGLL) to Palma de Mallorca (LEPA), when passing to the west of Paris, wish to check the latest weather at aerodromes in the vicinity, in case of the need for an in-flight diversion.
 To obtain this information what single source of meteorological information, available through VHF, could the crew consult?

options.text: VOLMET
VORTAC
AIREP
ATIS

variant.question: The crew of an aircraft flying from London Heathrow (EGLL) to Palma de Mallorca (LEPA), when passing to the west of Paris, wish to check the latest weather at aerodromes in the vicinity, in case of the need for an in-flight diversion. To obtain this information what single source of meteorological information, available through HF, could the crew consult?

options.text: VOLMET
VORTAC
ATIS
AIREP

variant.question: The crew of an aircraft flying from London Heathrow (EGLL) to Palma de Mallorca (LEPA), when passing to the west of Paris, wish to check the latest weather at aerodromes in the vicinity, in case of the need for an in-flight diversion. To obtain this information what single source of meteorological information, available through HF, could the crew consult?

options.text: VOLMET via datalink
ATIS
AIREP
VORTAC

variant.question: What are the normal and official sources of meteorological information for an aircraft in flight?

options.text: VOLMET broadcast; ATIS; all ATS-units
VOLMET broadcast; ATIS, and from the ATS-units the TWR only
VOLMET broadcast; ATIS, and from the ATS-units the TWR, APP and FIC only
VOLMET broadcast; ATIS, and from the ATS-units the FIC only

variant.question: What are the normal and official sources of meteorological information for an aircraft in flight?

options.text: “VOLMET broadcast ATIS ALL ATS UNIT
ATIS, and from the ATS-units the TWR only”
ATIS, and from the ATS-units the FIC only”
“VOLMET broadcast

variant.question: The crew of an aircraft flying from London Heathrow (EGLL) to Palma de Mallorca (LEPA) when passing over Paris, wishes to check the latest weather at destination. What source of meteorological information can the crew consult?

options.text: VOLMET via datalink
AIREP
METAR
ATIS
Oral commentary on existing and expected meteorological conditions.
Collection of weather documents for a flight.
Meteorological information from automatic observation systems.
Printed documents, including charts or forms, containing meteorological information for a flight.
Oral commentary on existing and expected meteorological conditions
Meteorological information from automatic observing systems
Collection of weather documents for a flight
Printed documents, including charts or forms, containing meteorological information for a flight

variant.question:
A flight is planned to Malmo, Sweden (ESMS) and is expected to arrive at **1200** UTC on 29th November.
 
The METAR for Malmo states:
ESMS **290610Z** **30006KT** **0100** FG NSC MO2/MO2 **Q1025** NOSIG
The TAF for Malmo states:
ESMS **2906/2918** **31008KT** **0300** FG NSC BECMG **2909/2912** **1800** BR BECMG **2912/2915** **3500** HZ BECMG **2915/2918** **2000** BR
During the flight, the pilot is advised of the following METAR for Malmo:
ESMS **290910Z** **32008KT** **0400** FG OVC040 M01/M01 **Q1025** NOSIG
Considering the information available on departure, what weather should the pilot expect on arrival, and should that change after receiving the **0910** UTC METAR? The pilot could have expected the fog to have cleared to:

options.text: Mist at worst for the arrival, but the cloud cover reported at 0910 UTC might mean that fog conditions persist for longer than originally forecast.
Haze at worst for the arrival, and the increased visibility reported at 0910 UTC.
Mist at worst for the arrival, but the cloud cover reported at 0910 UTC is likely to cause the air to warm up, improving the visibility to better than was originally forecast.
Haze at worst for the arrival, and there is NO reason for the pilot to change his/her expectations.

variant.question: When flying en-route, a pilot experiences unforecast severe turbulence and icing. A met forecaster should issue which of the following:

options.text: SIGMET
SPECI
METAR
TEMPO

variant.question: Where can a pilot obtain information regarding en-route icing conditions?

options.text: SWC ( sig. weather chart) and SIGMET
SPECI and TREND
METAR and SIGMET
TAF and METAR

variant.question: A crew preparing to depart from Phuket Airport (VTSP) in Thailand on the 30th October receives the following message: VTSP CNL AD WRNG 2 300100/300300 What is the purpose of the message?

options.text: To cancel aerodrome warning number 2.
To correct an error in the validity period of aerodrome warning number 2.
To delay the start of the validity period of aerodrome warning number 2 from 01:00 to 03:00
To continue the validity of aerodrome warning number 2 until 03:00 UTC.

variant.question: Crew is in flight, from London to Madrid. When flying over France, what is the source of meteorological information information?

options.text: VOLMET.
ATIS.
AIREP.
VORTAC.
